answers.answer: Yes it will.Doc would not treat me until it was under control. Your blood tests will show up. They dont want to start TX if there is going to be more problems. My BS was good during TX 6 months post it is on the rise but the dragon is gone

I had pre-diabetes before starting treatment, which has somewhat worsened during and since, but they believe the progression was inevitable whether with or without tx for the hcv.  The main thing is to keep monitoring your blood sugar (get a glucose meter if you don't have one) and take whatever meds your doctor prescribes.Actually, during tx I kind of ignored my blood sugar as my treatment time was brief (I was genotype 2) and I had such trouble eating anything at all that if it went down easily, i ate it.  That pretty much meant a lot of ice cream.In any event, high blood sugar is something you will eventually need to deal with as it's usually not a temporary thing.  At some point you'd do best to see an endocrinologist, but now may not be that time.  But in my opinion, you can go ahead on the 28th despite the glucose problem.  Good luck and good health.
I forgot to say: Don't keep this a secret from your hep doctor.  He or she needs to know as much as possible about you in order to give you the best care.
